Review Title: Great Company, needs to increase pay
Pros: ADP is an excellent company with a great culture of letting people come to work as they are. It is a large organization with a lot of potential to move around in. The company has great, reliable products and a strong history of success. The management from top to bottom is in tune with current market situations, and people are encouraged to speak up with new ideas. Outside of pay, the benefits are also really solid.
Cons: The base salary starting out is shockingly low. The Associate District Manager salary is actually embarrassingly low compared to other organizations, it is almost laughable. The company seriously needs to evaluate the base pay for associates starting out to attract and retain great talent.

Pros: The pro's were great training, great products and a fair compensation for the roll.
Cons: Inappropriate comments from colleagues and confusing bonus structure.

Review Title: The company is ok. Get told I am lucky to work here but I don’t see it.
Pros:
Good health benefits
Good work life balance
If you get a good territory and partner alignment you are gonna do well here. If not and have a high turnover and young partners good luck. You are gonna struggle to pay bills
Cons:
Low ball salaries for high stress.
Management gets promoted to management with no prior leadership experience. They just get the role as a consolation prize for being with the company for so long. 
Large org easy to get lost in the weeds on being just a number.
Management would rather manage you out the company and keep a revolving door by bringing in someone they hope will do the job instead of leading and training current person to do it.
Favorites are definitely a thing.
CEO Maria black came to the office and didn’t attempt to speak to any employees. Although she walked through the building she didn’t acknowledge any of us including management like we are some Peons.

Pros: Good Culture. Work with other generally intelligent people. Promotes from within. Flexible schedule. Great training. Product is oftentimes necessary for businesses. ADP is a familiar name for prospects. Good centers of influences, partnerships with banks/CPAs. Business doesn’t have to come all from cold calling. Good gas reimbursement.
Cons: Lower base pay. Lower OTE. Boring product - tough to stay motivated. Particularly tough if you have an unfavorable territory. Some territories are MUCH better than others. Management can be pushy at times. Management favors reps with higher quotas. Typical corporate fluff and lack of transparency when it comes to things happening higher up in the organization.

Review Title: Great People but Poor Training and Inadequate Resources/Support
Pros: People are great, remote work options, management means well and tries to offer support.
Cons: First and foremost, training has been severely lacking for a few years. You get minimal training watching videos or recordings. It's a "fend for yourself" culture of trying to get up to speed while attempting to offer a satisfactory level of service to clients. There is also a poor time off structure (not as many Holidays or PTO as other comparable companies). Not to mention, often times employees don't feel able to take time off for any length of time due to being overloaded with work and extra challenging deadlines that need to be met on multiple projects. Management tries to help but often seem to have their hands tied with regard to assisting with arranging desperately needed training and adequate resources.

Pros: Great Sales Training, was great culture (can go in & out depending on leader), uncapped commissions, great benefits/401-k/stock purchase program, great work-life balance and vacation flexibility, not too difficult a job, great referral partnerships
Cons: It's a grind as it's all new business sales. You're ultimately just a number and can be let go at any time for anything, with no debate or deliberation or consideration of the person you are and have been to the company. No way for senior leadership to back you Not the highest base in the industry.

Review Title: Not as great as I'd hoped
Pros:
It's a large company, so there is plenty of opportunity for growth for both vertical and horizontal moves. 
Ans relatively good base pay.
Cons:
Inconceivably extreme micromanagement environment masked by the concept of "feedback". It's not feedback; it's micromanagement. I cannot make up that once I supposedly "used the wrong shade of blue" on a document. I even had internal Microsoft Teams messages reviewed before I could hit send to other internal employees.

Get it right the first time or be castigated is the status quo and strangely accepted by everyone.

Unrealistic workload expectations with a workaholic company culture with some employees even bragging about how late they had to stay up to work. 

You'll have no say into your own work. Do what the highest paid person in the room says to do, even if it completely contradicts previous directions from the exact same person.

Hardly the best benefits, especially for a company that specializes in that sort of thing.

Review Title: Great place to start... not a great place to stay
Pros:
I personally really loved worked here for a variety of reasons:
1. Autonomy/flexibility. I never felt like someone was breathing down my neck making sure I was working. (could depend on your manager)
2. The people. Wow the people are really incredible.
3. Great intro to sales
Cons:
The management is super young (early to mid 20's) and so are the people they hire so it can just feel really juvenile at times.
Growth is also super limited here if you don't want to go into sales leadership...
It is honestly a lot of work to keep up with for the amount of pay (>70k). Full sales cycle plus maintaining referring relationships is very exhausting.

Pros:
Global industry leader- excellent insights, trends, data, etc.
Unfortunately, everything is like an episode of the twilight zone when you work there…
The contrast between the vision and insights the CEO and company provides the world vs. middle management’s conceptual understanding and adoption of best current trends and practices COULDN’T BE FURTHER APART FROM EACH OTHER.
This will drive you mad if you have any experience in b2b business development, channel sales, or brains in general…
Extremely disappointing to watch every good faith, hard earned sale get ultimately “No Start” because the client is disgusted with the implementation issues for so long they just pull the plug.  And ADP punishes a sales person for this- when the sales person has literally zero control over the implementation experience and technical aspects of that 20+ person team.
Sucks. Because theres a great opportunity for ADP revenue to grow significantly in markets where these clueless managers are- and instead they fail and the employees are failed, and ultimately the geographical community is failed by inability for mid sized businesses to be supported with innovation from ADP.
Cons: See pros.  Basically all tied together

Pros: Great work/life balance while still provided opportunities for career growth and development.
Cons: Some organizations with ADP have had a difficult time properly planning out resources through the current economy.

Review Title: Good pay and benefits, but lots of layoffs
Pros: The company has good pay, an annual bonus and strong benefits. Most people I worked with were great.
Cons: There were numerous layoffs while I was with the company. The company is not loyal to tenured employees. I saw so many great performers and employees that had 8+ years successful of experience with the company get laid off. There does not seem to be any rhyme or reason as to direct management team.

Pros: good benefits, great people / coworkers
Cons: I can honestly say I don't know very many happy employees at ADP. We used to be happy, during covid19 work from home order. Everything shifted when they started enforcing their extremely strict RTO policy that exhausts and threatens talented employees. Morale and motivation is low. There's also the increased pressure employees are feeling with a large # of projects/go-lives with unrealistic timelines, how long it takes to be recognized for your work and how little you get paid to do it.

Pros: I thoroughly appreciated my time at this company. The leadership team was consistently supportive, and the treatment of associates was commendable. Additionally, the company offered various perks, including free monthly Starbucks, bi-monthly cake days, and numerous events and treats organized by employee groups (BRGs).
Cons: The compensation at ADP could be more competitive, and there is room for improvement in terms of growth opportunities. Within my team, upward mobility was limited, and seeking advancement outside of my department would have required starting at a lower level and gradually progressing to a Project Manager role. Ultimately, I made the decision to leave because I received an offer for a role aligned with Project Management responsibilities, accompanied by a 47% increase in salary. While I valued my time at ADP, the new opportunity was too compelling to decline.

Review Title: Wonderful Coworkers and Opportunity for Growth
Pros: The best part about ADP for me has been the opportunities for further development. I have a wonderful manager who is supportive of my desire to continue to grow within the company. Also, my team is great. I love every single one of my coworkers. We are all very supportive of each other. We are still hybrid so I enjoy the ability to work from home twice a week. I also feel fairly compensated for the first time EVER.
Cons: This particular role takes inbound calls which for me is emotionally taxing. Most calls are fine, but it is the unknown of what's coming next. This role has you glued to the phone and every minute of your day is tracked. I wish I was able to spend more time with my team face to face. It is very much a corporate office/cubicle environment, but my section is very bright with large windows and the design is modern. So that keeps my mood up.

Pros: fantastic co-workers and overall team

Review Title: The rich get richer at ADP
Pros:
Big company
Good reputation
ESPP
Cons: Your success is largely based on who is looking out for you and who you are partnered with. Internal partnerships between different business units are instrumental towards your success. External partners (CPA’s, bankers, brokers) can also refer you business but are typically already aligned to the more tenured reps. It’s a nice little machine they have producing business… The top performing reps get paired with other tenured/high performing reps. New hires get paired with other new hires which is like the blind leading the blind. These tenured high performers are paid handsomely and it felt like the rich always got richer. Clients feel like once they join ADP they are sold every product/service under the ADP sun.
